Eli Sisters.Action: Covers Charlie while reloading guns and kicks in the door to protect his brother.
Light two lamps after gunfire to provide light and hands one to Charlie.
Steps over corpses silently without showing explicit brutality or cruelty.
Climbs up to the roof, warns Charlie about the barn fire, shows situational awareness.
Tries to save horses from barn fire despite danger, coat catches fire, manages to put it out with help.
Disregards Charlie's advice to leave, take a risky action to save horses.
Acknowledges failure bluntly ('Well, we fucked that up real good.'), shows reflective understanding of the situation.
Drinks less than his brother and listens attentively to the conversation about the job details.
Expresses concern about fairness in payment, saying it is bad business to short the man underneath.
Does not press for full details about the job, showing trust in his brother's judgment.
Dresses sloppily and appears physically disengaged while waiting, showing low alertness or preparation.
Questions the fairness of payment for the lead man, indicating awareness of business and team dynamics.
Does not inquire about the specifics of the job despite the opportunity, possibly showing lack of curiosity or strategic thinking.
Tries to catch up with his brother and actively engages in conversation about job logistics.
Expresses concern about the horses being unsuitable for the job and insists on getting a new horse as promised, showing practicality and a need to be treated fairly.
Calls out Charlie for not supporting his need, stands his ground against teasing, showing sincerity and assertiveness without cruelty.
Keeps his room clean and tidy compared to Charlie's messy room, reflecting personal discipline and respect for space.
Asks Charlie for help cutting his hair, demonstrates friendliness and openness in family interaction.
Questions the adequacy of the horses for the mission, insisting on having proper equipment for the job.
Thinks it over before responding to Charlie, showing consideration before acting.
Insists on immediate need for a horse, not deferring practical concerns to later.
Offers to pay the bartender's bill for Charlie, demonstrating responsibility and initiative.
Asks Charlie for help cutting his hair, showing self-awareness and attention to personal readiness.
Does not directly confront or escalate argument about equipment beyond reasonable limits.
Questions and challenges Charlie's use of the word 'victimized' regarding the Commodore, showing concern about implications.
Follows routine to collect tin pans and silverware and stoke fire without complaint, maintaining camp duties calmly.
Engages in somewhat tense discussion with Charlie but avoids escalation, indicating restraint.
Questions the logic behind theft from the Commodore and critically analyzes the situation.
Insists on precise language and challenges Charlie’s casual word choice, indicating attention to detail.
Follows the well-established camp routine by collecting tin pans and silverware, and stoking the fire.
Spreads out a blanket and patchwork quilt for camp, winds pocket watch, prepares a comfortable resting place
Responds to Charlie’s teasing about his relationship with Miss Emilia Patridge with mild annoyance but keeps privacy intact
Discusses family and father’s madness calmly with Charlie, showing understanding and restraint
Collects tin pans and silverware and stokes the fire according to a well-established routine.
Spreads out blankets and prepares his resting place with attention to detail, winding his pocket watch.
Checks his watch and moves the big hand deliberately.
Shows confusion about Charlie's insinuations about Miss Emilia Patridge and marriage plans, responding cautiously.
Engages in a serious conversation about family, mental illness, and inherited traits, showing thoughtful reflection.
Shows curiosity and interest in peaceful, civilized life (contemplating owning a store, admiring the trading post).
Expresses desire to stop killing and settle into a peaceful, honest life.
Gently points out Charlie’s emotional vulnerability (says Charlie cries sometimes).
Carefully examines new tools and items in the store with curiosity and interest.
Expresses a thoughtful and mature desire to settle down and leave violence behind, showing reflective judgment.
Engages in a calm and perceptive conversation, noticing emotional states and mental stresses in his brother.
Eats soup served by a woman selling it, attempts polite conversation about the food despite language barrier.
Diligently brushes his teeth according to instructions, inventing a style, showing personal care but no social interaction.
Watches a family observing the Sabbath ritual quietly and respectfully.
Brushes his teeth diligently and excessively, inventing a style according to instructions.
Observes surroundings carefully while eating, showing vigilance.
Engages with local culture by tasting soup and attempting to communicate about it.
Gives up trying to communicate when the woman does not understand.
Grabbed his gun and ran to the window immediately after hearing gunshots, showing alertness and readiness.
Watches Charlie act recklessly and shoots into the air but chooses to go back to bed instead of intervening.
Turns to the wall and shuts his eyes when Charlie enters, avoiding confrontation and not engaging with his brother’s drunken behavior.
Remains calm when brother cocked a revolver near his ear, opening his eyes and telling him to go to sleep without panic.
Hears a thump and immediately stops his horse to attend to Charlie who is down, showing attentiveness and responsibility.
Grabs Charlie roughly and helps him back into the saddle after he vomits
Turns away silently and refuses to talk when Charlie asks if he is pouting
Smiles slightly despite being accused of pouting and ruining the mood
Grabs Charlie roughly but helps him back into the saddle after he vomits, showing practical care and decisiveness in a difficult moment.
Stops his horse and confronts Charlie about his behavior, setting clear communication boundaries by telling him to either ride in front or back and that he doesn’t feel like talking.
Remains mostly silent and pouts, showing passive resistance rather than actively resolving conflict or communicating effectively.
Smiles slightly when pretending to pout despite Charlie’s teasing, indicating self-awareness and emotional control rather than genuinely sulking.
Feels moved by his brother's pain and gently wakes him up despite his own discomfort.
Looks peeved at brother's teasing but still shares a laugh with him.
Turns back multiple times while riding alone looking for brother, showing concern.
Deciphers the letter he found among debris while riding, showing attention to detail and literacy.
Sleeps but half-opens his eyes and feels reassured by his brother's watchfulness, indicating trust in others rather than personal vigilance.
Has a spider that climbs inside his mouth without reacting, suggesting a moment of absentmindedness or lack of alertness.
Lies shivering and sick, does not complain but quietly endures his pain.
Does not respond fully to Charlie's concern, indicating reservedness or reticence.
Eli struggles physically with illness, shows weakness and lack of control over his condition.
Eli does not react strongly or try to mask his suffering; he is vulnerable and somewhat passive in his condition.
Allows Charlie to help and support him when sick and weak without complaint.
Expresses vulnerability honestly by admitting sickness and tiredness to Charlie.
Uses a harsh phrase ('Fuck you!') when responding to Charlie's comment.
Observes surroundings calmly after waking up, shows concern about the bear attack on horses and Tub's injuries by asking what happened and looking closely at Tub's wound.
Mentions having a dream about Pa’ to Charlie, indicating a personal and possibly vulnerable moment shared with his brother.
Remains conscious after a rough night, observes surroundings carefully, assesses the damage from the bear attack.
Asks questions to gather information about what happened during the night.
Mentions having a dream about Pa’ but shows no immediate reaction or decision based on it.
No direct action or statement present in the excerpt to evaluate warmth.
Pushes Morris gently awake, avoiding confrontation despite Morris waking with a gun.
Speaks candidly about his fear of torture and suffering, showing vulnerability.
Reflects on the cruelty of the world, indicating a critical, empathetic view.
Generally silent and non-confrontational after expressing fears.
Demonstrates careful observation and restraint by not escalating conflict despite tense situations.
Engages with volatile individuals and maintains composure amid threats and duplicity.
Does not intervene or act decisively in situations where it might be warranted (omission).
Almost shoots someone trying to open a window but immediately unlocks gun upon realizing it is his brother Charlie, showing cautiousness and quick correction.
Looks carefully around the hotel for threats before approaching, indicating responsibility and care for safety.
Responds calmly and sensibly to the frustrating news about Warm's departure and suggests continuing with the plan.
Points at the barman to say something louder in a sarcastic but engaging way.
Confronts Charlie about his drunkenness and accountability for delays.
Follows Charlie out after a tense exchange, showing concern despite conflict.
Points to the barman and demands he hears the plan louder, showing awareness of surroundings and intent to communicate clearly.
Questions the pace and progress of the mission, noticing the target may be farther ahead and showing critical assessment of their situation.
Deflects blame onto Charlie’s drunkenness instead of accepting responsibility for slowing down, showing defensiveness rather than accountability.
Expresses a vision to found a new society focused on spiritual development and education of children, not just profit.
Smiles and shares an intricate drawing symbolizing partnership and friendship, showing openness.
Asks the bartender directly about a man they are looking for, staying engaged when Charlie gives up, demonstrating persistence and clear communication.
Follows Charlie into the saloon 'as best he can,' implying some physical struggle or lesser ability to keep up, indicating possible lower physical capacity or hesitation.
Engages in light conversation about the town name, showing some observational humor but no clear indication of competence.
Put off by Charlie's bragging to unsettle others.
Sternly states they will leave first thing, showing straightforwardness.
Questions Charlie about telling everyone their life story, showing concern.
Sighs and predicts Charlie will drink too much and be sick, implying caring responsibility.
Stops Charlie from revealing their employer and identity, indicating caution and strategy.
Shows disapproval of Charlie's excessive drinking and reckless bragging.
Remains silent and allows Charlie to make a scene and potentially risk their safety or reputation.
Sternly states they will leave early, showing control over their plans.
Stops a woman from pouring a drink for Charlie, asserting that he can pour his own liquor.
Initiates a conversation with a girl by the piano and tries to arrange a believable exchange regarding a shawl gift with her, coaching her to deliver the lines meaningfully.
Becomes frustrated when the woman is unable to improvise or deliver the lines with genuine feeling.
Is at the bar looking embarrassed and looks away.
Gently kisses a woman who is unaccustomed to kindness; shows concern when she turns away in tears, asks if he hurt her.
Insists on paying; grabs her arm briefly but relents when she asks to go.
Reads the woman’s lips and shows concern for her safety with ‘Be careful’ and questions to understand.
Searches for Charlie in questionable surroundings, urges him to wake and prepare despite Charlie’s reluctance.
Helps Charlie put on his boots, tries to motivate him to be alert and capable.
Reads lips correctly to understand a warning ('May-field!').
Moves stealthily around the saloon, checking rooms to find Charlie.
Successfully rouses Charlie from a drunken stupor and prepares him by putting on his boots.
Fails to adequately control or manage Charlie's state, who is still intoxicated and unfit to act confidently.
Shows emotional gentleness and attempts a consensual kiss, but does not assert dominance or control.
Calms down a tense situation by suggesting to negotiate peacefully with the trappers
Tosses a gun to Charlie without looking, showing trust and coordination
Calls out Mayfield sarcastically after her death, showing insensitivity to her fate and the plight of the townspeople.
Analyzes the situation about investor Warm and Morris and deduces the potential value despite initial confusion.
Engages in and survives a violent confrontation resulting in the death of Mayfield and secures significant plunder.
Responds to townspeople with a dramatic but somewhat callous announcement about Mayfield’s death.
Discusses plans to torture Warm to get the formula, acknowledges violent methods.
Asks 'What the hell is a fortuitous energy?' showing curiosity and engagement with brother's words.
Comments realistically about the chaotic nature of San Francisco, 'there isn’t one [quiet spot] in this whole place!'
Questions and seeks clarification about 'fortuitous energy', showing curiosity and attention to detail.
Observes and comments on the chaotic nature of San Francisco realistically, demonstrating awareness of his environment.
Notes there won't be a quiet spot in the city, anticipating challenges in their mission setting, showing foresight.
Shows childlike curiosity and wonder at the hotel and its facilities (bath, water closet).
Suggests honesty to Charlie about failing to find Morris and Warm.
Contemplates leaving the violent business and settling down to a better life.
Curiously examines the water closet chain and figures out how it works, showing adaptability in an unfamiliar situation.
Feels unsure and confused about how to behave in the European-style restaurant with complex silverware, revealing unfamiliarity and discomfort in certain social settings.
Considers the strategic option of abandoning their mission by proposing to tell the truth they don’t have leads, demonstrating practical and critical thinking about their situation.
Suggests quitting the violent life and opening a store together, showing desire for change and a hopeful future.
Stares down Charlie without backing down when Charlie gets angry, indicating firmness but also willingness to engage sincerely.
Feels stunned and concerned when Charlie suggests trusting Sanchez and Rex, showing protective and caring feelings towards his brother.
Pays no attention to the money Charlie throws on the table, implying disinterest in materialism and focus on relational matters.
Asks why Charlie speaks as if they will part ways, indicating emotional attachment and care about their relationship.
Proposes the idea of quitting their violent trade and opening a store together, showing foresight and willingness to change life course.
Hesitates and struggles to articulate his alternative plan clearly, indicating some uncertainty or lack of confidence.
Remains calm and does not back down when Charlie reacts angrily, showing emotional control and courage.
Dismisses Rex as 'just a talking dog' but is stunned when Charlie suggests Sanchez, reflecting some underestimation or surprise.
Shows emotional sensitivity and appears moved by Charlie's decision and the separation hinted, suggesting introspection.
Expresses hurt over Charlie's rude words and physical aggression, grips revolver defensively but does not escalate violently.
Reflects silently and packs belongings after conflict, suggesting restraint and introspection.
Calls out Charlie for hitting him in public and refuses to tolerate disrespect, indicating limits to patience.
Physically strikes Charlie preemptively before Charlie can hit him again.
Instinctively grips the butt of his revolver when threatened, showing readiness and quick reflexes.
Thoughtfully packs his things after a troubled interaction, indicating self-control and deliberate decision-making.
Remains calm and firm in response to Charlie’s provocative behavior rather than escalating conflict impulsively.
Does not immediately react verbally to Charlie’s news, showing emotional restraint but also possibly a lack of engagement or enthusiasm.
Uses physical force decisively against Charlie before Charlie can strike him first, demonstrating confident and effective self-defense.
Shoos away flies and tries to clean Tub's infected horse wound
Holds a crude map and tries to find his bearings in the landscape, showing initiative and orientation skills.
Attempts to clean Tub’s infected eye and shoos away flies, indicating some practical care and attention to the horse’s condition.
Engages in prospecting curiosity ('I'd like to see how they go about it') suggesting a willingness to learn and adapt to new skills.
Does not act on Charlie’s suggestion to go ahead but instead pursues own interests, which shows some self-direction or confidence.
Encourages Tub gently to eat and shows care, takes time to fold shawl carefully, indicating thoughtfulness and emotional intelligence.
Eli opens his eyes upon hearing a noise and stands up in a daze when confronted, appearing disoriented and unprepared for the attack.
States firmly that they no longer work for the Commodore, showing assertiveness and clarity in his position.
Is handcuffed and captured along with Charlie, indicating failure to avoid capture or anticipate danger.
Comes up with a clever idea, recognized by Charlie as a 'genius' moment.
Responds evasively to Charlie's praise without elaborating or asserting confidence.
Offers help reassuringly to Warm during the gunfight.
Calmly offers help to Warm during a chaotic gunfight, indicating presence of mind and concern for allies.
Identifies the opposing men as likely belonging to Mayfield's group, showing situational awareness.
Follows Charlie's instructions during the gunfight without hesitation, demonstrating disciplined cooperation.
Agrees to split the profits half and half with the others, showing willingness to share and compromise.
Silently observes tension and conflict between others, without escalating or intervening.
Agrees to split the proceeds from the river according to the suggestion, showing willingness to cooperate and engage in negotiation.
Passively lets Morris express disagreement and tension without intervening or de-escalating the situation.
Holds back Charlie to reduce tension, encourages calm dialogue.
Shows understanding of Morris's mistrust, acknowledges necessity of change.
Waves to Morris who barely reacts; Eli still initiates friendly gesture despite lack of response.
Washes at the river in the early morning and demonstrates calm observance of surroundings and companions without direct conflict.

In the broader context of accompanying the group during technical activities like prospecting and observing the river’s flow, participates cooperatively (implied), showing basic functional capability but no standout skill.
Invites Charlie to join the group around the fire to relax and have fun
Acknowledges the futility of trying to sleep, shares the mood of drinking and laughing together
Finds Tub, the lost horse, motionless in the ravine and looks saddened.
Silently sits by the river watching the sun and trout, contemplative rather than engaging.
Notices the missing horse Tub and immediately goes to investigate, tracking blood and hoof prints to find Tub injured at the bottom of a ravine.
Sits quietly reflecting on the environment and his situation after discovering Tub’s injury.
Admits emotional pain about his dead horse and his troubled past, including his father's death and responsibility toward his brother Charlie.
Expresses care and loyalty toward his brother Charlie despite his violence.
Shows vulnerability and openness in conversation with Warm, engaging sincerely.
Mentions that talking about his experiences with Warm feels strange, indicating some discomfort but still openness.
Reflects on the consequences of Charlie's violence and accepts responsibility for handling difficult family situations.
Shows physical weakness and dizziness during the walk, requiring help from Warm.
Openly admits emotional vulnerabilities, such as grief over his dead horse and regret about past events.
Engages in thoughtful conversation with Charlie about difficult topics like killing the Commodore and what comes after.
Shows hesitation and considers consequences, indicating empathy and reflective nature.
Works cooperatively with Charlie, Morris, and Warm during the river dam operation despite unpleasant conditions.
Considers the consequences of killing the Commodore and questions the practical next steps.
Engages in thoughtful dialogue about future plans and replacements, showing strategic thinking.
Hesitates when faced with the implication of taking over the Commodore's role, suggesting some uncertainty.
Stops to smile warmly while watching his companions work, sharing a moment of silent appreciation and camaraderie.
Urgently tells Charlie to stop dumping the harmful chemical into the river, showing concern for safety and environment.
Attempts to help Warm by entering his tent and asking if he can do something for him despite Warm’s severe condition.
Sincere exchange with Warm, acknowledging friendship when Warm expresses regret and desire to be friends.
Stands straight and alert immediately after a gunshot inside the tent, showing calmness and concern.
Carefully packs their treasure into saddlebags showing responsibility and care.
Leaves the tent quietly after feeling a presence, showing respect and sensitivity.
Reflects on happiest moments appreciating simple pleasures and freedom, expressing sincere and good-natured introspection.
Carries injured Charlie on his back through difficult terrain despite the ordeal, showing devotion and tolerance.
Rushes to help Charlie after he falls, showing prompt care and concern.
Chases fly away from Charlie’s mouth and wipes his brow during unconsciousness, exhibiting tenderness and protectiveness.
Manages to fit their treasure into Warm and Morris’ horse’s saddlebags efficiently.
Ties weakened Charlie to his back in steep passes, adapting to difficult terrain to keep moving.
Rushes to help Charlie immediately after he falls from his horse.
Cares attentively for Charlie during his surgery by chasing away a fly, wiping his brow, and staying present.
Feels a presence when discovering the adventure diary and chooses to leave the tent, showing awareness and caution.
Urgently instructs Doctor Crane and tries to lift injured Charlie to escape danger
Respects Charlie’s silent command not to carry him despite wanting to help
Obeys Rex’s commands to avoid escalating the situation
Conceals Charlie’s guns when surrendering to deceive Rex
Cautiously assesses situation by looking out the curtain and noticing the men outside, showing awareness.
Quickly instructs the doctor to use the back door for escape and urges Charlie to move, demonstrating quick thinking and urgency.
Respects Charlie’s unspoken order and does not carry him despite wanting to, showing good judgment and discipline.
Follows the demands of Rex by tossing his belt and raising hands, but cleverly hides Charlie’s guns, indicating tactical cunning.
Some hesitation initially before fully acting, e.g., pauses before tossing guns and going out, which may indicate some anxiety or uncertainty.
Shoots a man lying in pain in the head without hesitation.
Crushes Rex’s back with his boot before firing at him.
Encourages to keep moving despite Charlie’s distress over lost treasure.
Watches others ride by from hiding to avoid confrontation.
Shoots into the shadows during a gunfight, tries to protect horses by ordering their safety.
Changes his brother’s bloody bandage and stands guard while Charlie cries.
Wants to help Charlie immediately but restrains himself, respects Charlie's space.
Offers reassurance and emotional support, telling Charlie he loves him despite the injury.
Quietly watches his brother’s sobs and protects him during the vulnerable moment.
Empties pan in fire and remains vigilant while brother sleeps.
Makes a violent threat about killing the Commodore.
Removes hat alongside townsfolk dressed in black, showing some respect at the Commodore's funeral.
Brings coffin lid down on the dead Commodore’s face, then raises hand to calm astonished onlookers.
Gently asks mother for permission to come home despite initial hostility
Observes and quietly reflects on family memories without interrupting
Lies down peacefully, soothed by family voices, showing emotional openness
Approaches cautiously and tries to calmly reassure his wary mother to allow them in.
Quietly observes the house and their old measuring rod, taking in details but remaining passive.
Lies down on his childhood bed, appearing soothed and unable to actively engage or assert himself in the situation.
